												I'm conflicted to whether I really like it, or simply like it. Trust me, there's a big difference. Either way, the game is definitely worth a look for hardcore racing fans to casual gamers looking to try something new.MX vs. ATV Reflex is an off road racing and stunt game made for enthusiasts. It's also perfectly welcoming to casual gamers with it's well rounded sensitivity (and accuracy) towards in-game accidents. I like the game, but little elements make me dislike it for not being better. The game itself is overall well put together and complimented by a welcoming and to the point visual tutorial. Overall, the gameplay is pretty respectable.The absolute first thing that bugged me was the first person view. I couldn't see the bike or handlebars until I was in motion or if the bike was bumping upwards. Going from MotoGP 13 first person to this is just absolutely horrible. It feels decently adequate but the feel of having absolute full control isn't here. To be in full control, one needs to play in third person view to completely enjoy the game and character stunt movements. My only other complaint is the steering. MotoGP isn't perfect in it's steering, but it feels quite realistic when doing so. Here, it feels choppy or sort of skippy. It doesn't interfere so much in the game play but for people looking for exact motor bike steering, it isn't exactly here. It feels like the game is caught between being an arcade game and a simulation game, such as it's unable to decide which one to be. I find that most successful racing games actually find a balance between the two, REFLEX may have just found it. They sort of force you to stay on course (and will make you respawn if you don't) but there's always a few options here and there to take your own sort of short cut off the track.Additionally, the game is quite gripping and provides for some serious fun. The different game modes include free-roam, race, and stunt. What makes this game quite unique though is that the right analog stick looks after the body movements while the left deals with the bike. This is a fantastic addition to the game as turns can be done on a dime if done right. This also helps rotate the bike in the air while doing stunts. Jumps are pretty rewarding and landings are decently accurate and feel right when their put together back to back. There is a system that exists within the game where if your character loses his balance, you have to use the right thumb stick and push it in a direction multiple times to avoid falling off the bike. Another system to be appreciated as it keeps you on your toes.The driving scheme in general is very beautiful once you get ahold of it. Graphics are absolutely fantastic as tire, bike and body marks on the ground are amazingly drawn. The terrain deformation is astounding. What bugs me the most is the first person view. I wouldn't mind seeing more of the handle bars. Then again, I may have been spoiled by playing MOTOGP first. In addition to the bikes (and unfortunately), players cannot see inside of the buggie or the pick-up truck when in first person as well. I would recommend running the settings first before launching the actual game. Going from 30 to 60fps left me speachless. In addition to good looks, the replays offer a highlight reel which is pretty solid. Watch some solid jumps be pulled off or accidents. The tracks are also well designed and differ from one another (from stadiums to snow-y mountains). Riders sometimes will move their head and check their peripherals while riding. Sounds are pretty decent. The engines vary between bikes and the crowd will make a "ohhh" sound if you wipe out. For future MX vs ATV games, the jerky feeling of the steering needs to be addressed. It doesn't feel real at all sometimes especially when making landings. Other times, landings to crashes are absolutely nailed.Overall a pretty good game worth buying especially if on sale. Sucks it doesn't have local co-op but it does have multiplayer if it matters.RATING : 7.45/10 Gameplay A- Story / Campaign B Visuals / User Interface B+ Sounds / Music B Replay-ability B Overall  B+ScreenShots : Me, getting bumped by a truck, which is also a part of this raceThe crash system is fun to abuse......especially when the computers start going at itTerrain deformation occurs even when the riders hit the groundMore unnecessary carnageThe body impact physics are on point Minimalistic first person view. Definitely not a fan of it This is a stunt  Wheelies and stoppies are possibleVideo :  MX VS ATV Highlights Review

content:
2016
 Reflex is still king, 2016. GAMEPLAY:There is plenty of content to take on in Reflex. For example, there's a handful of national and supercross tracks to race on. In addition, there are also a ton of different game modes for you to have fun with such as FMX competitions, racing off-road trucks, UTV's, or buggies etc. Most importantly (for me) is that the base game has a decent amount of customization options from gear, to bike parts, and graphic kits. ALTHOUGH, if you get sick of the same old skins (as well as tracks), then go visit http://reflex-central.com/ for some mods. Moving on, I've found it quite hard to always have a perfect lap considering that the track develops lines (or ruts) the more you ride on it. In other words, every lap feels like a different approach is needed unless you can follow through with your exact line perfectly.CONTROLS:While using a controller to play the game, you use the left analog stick to steer your bike and the right analog stick to control your rider. So if you were to ride a berm to the left, you would basically move both sticks to the left to make your rider lean into the berm. Furthermore, if you were to speed over some whoops, you would move the right stick only backwards so that your rider leans a bit back to absord the rough part of the track.ONLINE: I still find a ton of racers online in 2016. Although, online gameplay is where the cons are for me. For example, racing with other races can be challenging (or annoying) considering how it appears that your opponents are bouncing around all over the track. Furthermore, there is this thing known as the whip glitch that allows you to easily clear jumps. A lot of online racers abuse this, "whip glitch" making them ultimately faster than you unless you can do it too. If you want to have a fair race, play this game online with a friend. GRAPHICS & PERFORMANCE:I'm using a 3570k stock, 780 SC, and 16GB of RAM. With that said, performance is great. Although, I can remember it being not so great when I had AMD hardware. Moving on, the game still looks great in 2016 thanks to the power of PC gaming. For example, here is one of my screenshots @ 1440p.

OVERALL:9 out of 10, this game is a must have for any motocross/off-road racing fan. Do note that this game usually goes on sale on Steam for a few bucks and that's a steal! I have purchased this game so many times on Steam as gifts for others.

It is NOT a hardware issue, it is the absolute fault of the devs here.  It is NOT a driver issue, believe me, I have done way more than "normal" troubleshooting in a complete waste of time and you know what?  I bought this game for my son who at first was able to play through the horrible bugs but even he, being young, can't look past that anymore, and choses to just play on the "lobby" map for hours and has to quit the game and reload when it attempts to start a real map.Broken pile of garbage. Horrible company.I can only sit here and watch my son play MX vs ATV Reflex with it's terrible lag and video artifacts for so long until I am speechless as to how a company that is supposed to be professional can refuse to fix blatant, game-breaking problems. Support is apathetic. They do not care. My son plays this game. As a child, who is obsessed with dirt bikes, he has learned how to play this game and embrace the absurdity. The bugs and glitches have become "just part of the game" for him. He is a child, willing to do anything to find enjoyment where all I see is amateur mistakes.He blamed me at first, and I had to go through the motions of trying out 3 other graphics cards that didn't work just to satisfy his curiosity as for the longest time he thought it was my r9 290x and GTX 770 cards that weren't "working" right. Truth be told, he has actually learned a lot from this ordeal, and I have used the opportunity to teach him more about how computers work. He got to see dad taking apart three different systems, install three different versions of windows, so this was not at all a waste of time; Should Nordic feel proud of this? Making a game that has a myriad of problems that it makes other "problem" games seem better by comparison? Letting what I assume was to be a flagship title fester and stagnate so that only a small percentage of buyers could actually play the game without having to incorporate AWFUL graphics issues like 5 frames per second and full screen artifacts? There is no excuse for this. Thankfully I've persuaded him to branch out to other racing games, and he is becoming more interested in all things motorcycle, and the Saints Row games have been providing him enough diversion to not care about the next game in this series, and I've alleviated the stress for both of us by promising him GTA V when it's released. As a gamer, I usually never go on a tirade about bad business practices in this industry because let's face it, since the 80's we've had to, by trial and error, learn how to not let little stuff get to us. If this were a game I erroneously bought for myself at any other time I would have chalked it up to a bad buying decision and a need for me to find demos or do more research before opening up my wallet. Sadly, as a parent, I did not afford myself or my family the luxury of knowledge this time around, and I've been rewarded with a 8 year old child who through no fault of his own has had to learn and endure way more than I ever thought a stupid videogame would introduce.It's sad. Now he thinks he has to play the game and try to show dad that he can have fun and justify the purchase. No matter how many times I tell him it's OK, it isn't his fault, he still wants to make me happy. So I wake up on weekends hearing this game's bikes go RRRRR RRRREER and he puts on a display how much fun he's having. He plays so that I can see for a while, and I have to tell him it's OK if he does something else. Thanks Nordic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. ♥♥♥♥ you for disappointing my kids. After all this time, your only excuse is that you dont give a ♥♥♥♥.

												My GF got me this game, and we played it together expecting a PC quality game, what we got has the feel of a last minute port from xbox 360.The graphics are pretty good, but have few actual settings, and your tire tracks shine and sparkle, whether it's in mud, dirt, or snow. Snow and mud make sense, but dirt does not sparkle nor shine, so that is poorly done.The dynamic terrain is mostly astetic, you need to race several laps to where the dirt piles into mounds before it will actually effect your driving, whether it's in a vehicle or the (what should be) much more sensitive to terrain motocross bike.The only controller supported is the Xbox 360 one, which is sad since legacy controller support like most PC games use will let you map ANY controller, if you use ANY other controller, have xpadder on hand, and be ready for worse sensitivity than you should ever have with an analog stick.Another thing on sensitivity, there isn't any settings for it on keyboard, or even if you use the supported controller, so expect to do hard turns on smooth corners a lot.Tilting should have you Lean and break/gas/steer, the game is supposed to be specifically for the combination of leaning, and throttle/break/steering, but leaning wont effect forward and back tilting in the air, not even on MX, it's only the gas and break, it's unrealistic when you can lean backwards but you tilt forwards because you're breaking, and invalidates the game's primary selling point.Air time is a little bit much and vaguley borderline realistic, it doesn't really bother gameplay since most people enjoy the extra air time, nor does it stand out as arcade-esk airtime.All in all, if you still use the dated 360 controller for gaming on PC (Or you like keyboards for racing games), you dont mind the graphics of a last minute console port, and you dont really care about the whole "reflex" part of the game (since it's vaguley there), you may like this game.Personally, we did not, she would have asked for a refund but it was on sale and this game was about worth the $10 she paid for 2 copies.

												Now I know what your thinking. MX vs ATV? How can it be bad? Well it probably is...on a console. MX vs ATV Reflex is one sad excuse of a PC port. The game runs terribly. I can barely get 20 FPS even running on very low settings. Also the graphics aren't really that good. There kind of sloppy, and you can see where the developers added little pretties to hide the ugly monster within. Another thing to mention is the cameras. This game holds the most dimwitted camera system there is. And adding the lagginess to the game makes the camera even worse. It nearly gives you motion sickness. There is another thing that is bad to. The sounds. Oh my goodness the sounds! They go from making your ear drums bleed to quiet whispers with no transition. Also the developers have clearly never heard of the fact that trucks and most offroad vehicles have a thing called a transmission. The sound is just a loop. You never change up or down, so all you hear is a constant poorly recorded single engine note the entire time. It is just annoying. And as I said about the cameras, when you add the laginess it is much worse.Now I try to find good in everything. And I am happy to say this game does have a few things going this way, such as the amazing terrain deformation and the somewhat cool tricks system.But sadly those cool features are overtaken by the badness and the little silly things that are just annoying. You saw the things above, but guess what? Theres more. The developers thought it was vital to our gameplay experience to add scadily dressed line girls and a narrarator that sounds like batman. There is also use of words such as "rad" and "knarly" which is ok, but a little overdone if you know what I mean. Now ok, I understand the clients that they are trying to get to, such as real offroad enthusiasts like this kind of thing. But newsflash!  Real offroad enthusiasts have real offroad toys, so why would they play this silly game when they could go out (in real life) and thrash around on there motorcycle? See what I'm getting to? For us normal joes who just want to play a motorcycle game. We don't need line girls, or words of yobs. We just want to thrash around on a virtual motorcycle. This fact and the horrid laginess gets this game what it deserves.Rating 3.5/10 Also posted on the Do's and Don'ts steam group. For more game reviews, give us a visit.

Every vehicle feels like its made of helium and proceeds to bounce around the track on the edge of control. The stunt system was just made obtuse to be obtuse, Up-Left-Down=Trick. Just a shoddy poorly programmed dirtbike game saddled with a "Reflex system" that only serves to complicate and frustrate the rider and the quicktime hard landing event is just the final straw. I tried to like this but it really fights with me, for every good there is a bad and the Reflex system just leads me to ask "Why?". I want to push up on the same thumbstick I am using to steer, its natural but with Reflex they moved it to the other Thumbstick. 												In MX vs ATV Reflex, you get to race a whole load of vehicles, but it's really all about the motorbikes! To start with, I definitely recommend a controller for this game!When you first play this (The motorbike that is), you might be put off by the control system...because it's not like your usual car game where you use one stick for steering. In MX vs ATV you use both. One stick is your steering and the other is your body placement, allowing for full control of your angle when taking a tight corner.Don't let this put you off...stick to it and be patient with learning it, because once you have, it reveals what a satisfying racing and game play experience this title offers. You aren't limited to wining an A to B race, you can throw in awesome tricks (easily pulled off by pressing your left button and moving the right stick mid air), to gain more money allowing you to tweak your rides (better tires, exhausts that affect performance), and looks (both vehicles and rider). Once you've won a race or two in career mode, and tweak your bike with better stuff, your ability to pull off crazy tricks in a race is raised! You don't only get to race against others...there are exploration modes where you motocross your way to different markers on huge maps, and take some challenges. These vary from Hill Climb events, to jump accuracy events and so on..Personally I am glad I purchased this title (got it cheap) but honestly it's enough fun to recommend at full price too. Personal Rating: A fun engrossing racer, with good graphics and satisfying gameplay. Good Graphics, Lots of Mud, and hilarious when you get a stunt wrong and end up face planting into a tree!Percentage Rating: 85% Not for people wanting a quick arcade fix, this is nearly the perfect balance between arcade and simulation!

												MX vs ATV: Reflex is an impressive offroad racing game which, contrary to its title, allows you to drive not only two classes of MX bikes and ATVs but also several types of offroad cars, from buggies to 4x4 trucks.Developed by the team behind the classic Motocross Madness series, MX vs ATV offers a variety of racing modes across closed stadium and outdoor tracks as well as several open-world maps in different climate zones, from mudland to snowy mountains. What makes MX vs ATV particularly fun (and authentic) is the combination of precise controls (including weight shifting) and ground deformation. Only a few games have so far featured the latter (Sega Rally Revo did it best). Every vehicle leaves a track in the ground, changing the surface and making subsequent laps more difficult. This makes for an additional challenge, especially in longer races.Graphics are decent, but it's obvious that the game was made with consoles in mind. The level of texture detail and draw distance are limited, as are filtering and anti-aliasing features.This is a very fun and content-rich offroad racing game that appeals in particular to fans of the old Motocross Madness series.

												In MX vs ATV Reflex, you get to race a whole load of vehicles, but it's really all about the motorbikes! To start with, I definitely recommend a controller for this game!When you first play this (The motorbike that is), you might be put off by the control system...because it's not like your usual car game where you use one stick for steering. In MX vs ATV you use both. One stick is your steering and the other is your body placement, allowing for full control of your angle when taking a tight corner.Don't let this put you off...stick to it and be patient with learning it, because once you have, it reveals what a satisfying racing and game play experience this title offers. You aren't limited to wining an A to B race, you can throw in awesome tricks (easily pulled off by pressing your left button and moving the right stick mid air), to gain more money allowing you to tweak your rides (better tires, exhausts that affect performance), and looks (both vehicles and rider). Once you've won a race or two in career mode, and tweak your bike with better stuff, your ability to pull off crazy tricks in a race is raised! You don't only get to race against others...there are exploration modes where you motocross your way to different markers on huge maps, and take some challenges. These vary from Hill Climb events, to jump accuracy events and so on..Personally I am glad I purchased this title (got it cheap) but honestly it's enough fun to recommend at full price too. Personal Rating: A fun engrossing racer, with good graphics and satisfying gameplay. Good Graphics, Lots of Mud, and hilarious when you get a stunt wrong and end up face planting into a tree!Percentage Rating: 85% Not for people wanting a quick arcade fix, this is nearly the perfect balance between arcade and simulation!
